metadata.title: MacEwan Room Booking Redesign
metadata.description: A mobile redesign of MacEwan’s room booking system focused on improving usability, accessibility, and speed for students managing study and group sessions.

projectSummary.description: A mobile app for MacEwan students that streamlines room reservations with simplified flows, progressive disclosure, and filters for amenities like TVs, whiteboards, and accessibility features.
projectSummary.role: I conducted user research, mapped user flows, and applied Material Design to the design. I also ensured the app was accessible and contributed to designing booking features across design stages.

contents.text: The MacEwan Room Booking Services, as it stands, presents several usability and accessibility challenges for its users. To start our process, my team and I conducted user research through empathy mapping and persona development. I helped identify how users interact with the current room booking system and uncover key frustrations, goals, and gaps in usability.

items.text: Users are trying to choose rooms based on date, time, and amenities, often expressing confusion about features and clutter.
The interface is overwhelmed with excess calendar months, ambiguous icons, and headers styled like links, making navigation and interpretation difficult.

Users feel frustrated by inconsistent booking flows, stressed by excessively irrelevant options, and worried about missing essential room features, leading to anxiety or embarrassment, especially when needing assistance.
Repeated messages like “You can’t book past the week” or “Click the row for details,” alongside concerns about unexplained error messages.
The homepage’s information hierarchy and link styling are inconsistent, with key navigation elements hidden in dropdowns, leaving users unsure where to click or how to find basic functions.

items.header: Inconsistent and Cluttered Flows for Booking and Modifying Reservations
items.text: Booking and modification screens overload users with irrelevant options like unavailable time slots and two-month calendars that overwhelm rather than guide.
Crucial filters, room details, and booking-management tasks are hidden behind low-contrast icons or buried menus, preventing users from easily finding and using them.

items.header: Essential amenities are hard to locate
items.text: Poor filter design and hidden room details make it difficult for users to quickly find rooms with key features like TVs, whiteboards, or accessibility options.

contents.statement: As a student, I want to quickly book a room for a group project so that I can effectively collaborate with my team.

persona.name: Alex Chen
persona.type: 2nd-year Bachelor of Design student at MacEwan
persona.quote: I know exactly what kind of space my team needs; I just want to book it quickly without dealing with broken links.
goals: Book group-friendly rooms with specific features (e.g., TV, whiteboard, seating for 8)
Reserve a quiet study space for solo prep before exams
Quickly complete bookings in under 10 minutes
painPoints: Gets stuck when error codes or broken links appear
Frustrated by cluttered or unclear navigation when in a rush
Struggles to find rooms with the right features due to poor filtering options

contents.text: To address these challenges, we redesigned the MacEwan Room Booking Services into a mobile application that introduces new features such as:

items.text: Prioritize essential features for students on the homepage, use clearly labelled buttons instead of misleading link styles, and nest staff content under a separate section.
Limit booking views to one week, hide unavailable slots, and use an intuitive filter panel with toggles for room criteria like equipment and accessibility.
Simplify modifications into two clear paths (change the time or change room), keep booking details visible, and default to hiding cancelled bookings with a toggle to show them.
Show full room info (capacity, equipment, accessibility, layout) clearly, replace hard-to-see icons with labelled toggles, and follow accessibility standards for contrast and usability.

contents.text: I collaborated with my team to reimagine the booking experience using insights from our earlier research. I contributed to the following with the help of my team:

items.header: Revised the user flow for streamlined navigation
items.text: We mapped out the current system to expose redundancies and pain points, then redesigned the flow to make key actions like booking and modifying reservations clearer and faster to complete.

items.header: Applied Material Design for visual consistency
items.text: By using Material 3 guidelines, we standardized components, spacing, and typography, creating a polished, modern UI that felt intuitive and institutionally branded.

items.header: Integrated accessibility considerations from the start
items.text: We used high-contrast elements, readable typography, and clear visual cues to ensure that users with low vision or limited dexterity could confidently interact with every screen.

contents.text: This project reinforced the value of user-centered design, especially in institutional systems where user needs vary widely. Through iterative testing and accessibility-first thinking, we created a solution that significantly improved efficiency and confidence for all user types.

items.header: Early persona involvement guided critical decisions
items.text: Including users from the beginning ensured our design addressed real-world challenges, especially for those less confident with digital tools.

items.header: Iterative prototyping saved time and revealed usability issues early
items.text: By creating a series of low to mid-fidelity prototypes, we gradually improved the layout, identified confusing interactions, and streamlined the overall user flow.

items.header: Accessibility was most effective when planned early
items.text: Building contrast checks, screen-reader support, and wayfinding considerations from scratch reduced rework and improved inclusivity.
